reviewText:
Part character brawler, part puzzle platformer with optional precision platformer sections, Guacamelee! is thoroughly enjoyable as a whole.

Drinkbox Studio masterfully combined movement and combat abilities in this lucha libre-themed metrovania. While requiring dexterous fingers at times, a perfectly executed series of moves that solves a puzzle room often results in what can only be described as pure joy.

Beyond the numerous references to video games and Internet memes, Guacamelee!'s clean and vibrant portral of Mexican culture and folklore stands on its own. Combined with the delightful soundtrack, my senses were pleasantly engaged throughout my playthrough.

It's a nice touch to view both endings without actually requiring to complete the optional objectives. At 6-8hrs, Guacamelee! didn't outstay its welcome and I'll probably return at some point to chip away at more of its side-content.

reviewText: This was a very well made platformer game. The fighting system is fun and has a lot of depth to it. It's basically a brawler with wrestling moves. There are lots of different moves that you can buy and unlock to attack enemies with. The platforming segments are all very well made and a lot of them are challenging to get through. The boss fights are also nicely designed. The game never feels too hard that it's unfair, but just hard enough to feel satisfying whenever you get past a hard encounter or boss fight. There are lots of references to other games and lots of Mexican/Spanish jokes. It only takes about 5 hours to finish, but you can add another 3 hours for the sidequests.

reviewText:
This game is a very well done game that was ported over from the consoles to the pc. The controls are very fluid,the graphis are easy on the eyes, the combat is fun and the adventuring keeps you wanting to play.Game runs very smoothly at all sections in it and the music keeps up with the pace of the game.The story is not great but not bad, is something kids might find more entertaining than adults,but better than nothing at all.

The combat in the game works like a beatem up where you can do combo's and after unlocking, use various skills which become part of your arsenal to take down mobs.There are boss fights which are a lot of fun and entertaining and though out quite well. Outside of the combat moves you can unlock there are different outfits which give different stats when you wear them.The adventuring is fun because all of the locations are unique to one another including the other dimension versions of each.Great care was done to the enivornments and locations to make them not reptitive in looks ,feel and play styles.

The only thing and I mean the only thing about this game they I cannot stand are the very few , and I mean very few puzzle-platform areas that will keep you doing them over and over again. I encountered three areas in the game that thanks to my patience I manged to do but two of the area's took me 30-45min to do soley because of constantly messing up. The third area is an area in which the puzzle is a long vertical jump,run,jump,climb,etc portion.After trying my hand at it for literally 5 hours of total gameplay time I decided I had enough with the game and uninstalled it.

Aside from the three area's I ran into I loved the game, but I will say this as a warning about those areas.

Final Thoughts
If you want to play a very actiony beatem up, platform puzzle game,can deal with a few sections you will have to try and try again to do, you will enjoy the game. I got about 2/3 the way finished before I had enough of the 3rd puzzle are that had me at bay and uninstalled. Enjoy my time with the game and it was lots of fun. You will have a blast.

reviewText:
It is a platform puzzler with spot-on controls. If you failed something, YOU made the mistake. Always the mark of a team who fine-tuned the hell out of the character movements.

It is a beat-em-up with an incredibly rewarding, fluid, make-your-own-combo fighting system. Want to punch a dude, uppercut him into the air, punch him some more while you float together, slam him back towards the ground, catch him before he lands and then suplex him into his evil friends? You can do that.

It is the only game I've ever cared to 100% in terms of achievements, because they were fun and (at times) challenging.

This is a game made for me, and you don't even go to space. Pure. Finely made. Fun.

reviewText:
Metroidvaina + Castle Crashers with just a dash of Super Meat Boy! = Guacamelee!

I purchased this game as soon as I saw that Metroidvaina was the general design of the game. I intended to test it out when I installed but ended up playing for 3 straight hours.

You'll play as Juan who dons the mask of legacy and becomes the Luchador. The game is filled with Mexican culture with modern internet-isms (memes as well) masked throughout. Don't let that push you away however, seeing iconic internet..uhh things in the game actually provide a bit of subjective art as I felt more connected as if the developers are one of us who are playing.

The controls are extremely fluid, with the ability to cancel out of any action with an air or ground dodge and the combat has just as much flow. You do a regular melee attack that can combo up to 3 hits with cardinal directional moves depending on if you are in the air or ground. Add another button dedicated to Special moves also with 4 directions of variety and you got a simplistic yet intricate combat system. Oh you can also toss opponents across the arena and into other skeletal hombres.

The exploration aspect is top notch with nook and crannys begging to be searched. You'll find places you can't reach due to some obstruction and be rewarded if you remember later down the road. At one point in the game, you'll have the power to switch from the light world to the dead world with platforming and combat creatively incoporated. While some secrets are obvious, you'll need to put on your master explorer hat to find everything Gucamelee! has to offer. The difficulty is just right, with the enemies requiring more finesse and the platforming demanding 2 or 3 actions in short time. For the daring, to 100% the game, Guacamelee! demands you to channel your inner Super Meat Boy and do some sadistc platforming challenges.

The soundtrack is fantastic with each area giving you a different Mexcian vibe. I always enjoyed hearing all of the pieces each and everytime I entered an area.

You can even have local 2 player coop!

There is a ton to say about Guacamelee! but I think you should save it for yourself. I personally recommend this game to anyone who enjoys beat-em ups/platformers/and exploration adventures (Castle Crashers, Metroid, Castlevaina, Super Meat Boy)

To fully complete the game (100% completion including Steam Achievements) I clocked in at about 10 hours.

Guacamelee!

reviewText:
Guacamelee is an action platform, of the Metroidvania variety. You play a Mexican Luchadore, fighting the forces of evil to save your love and the world. Along the way you will explore varied areas, learn new abilities, and fight a multitude of enemies.

Guacamelee is a game that is just oozing style. Everything from the artwork, to the sound, the writing, the characters and the world at large mesh so well together. You will want to spend time exploring the world and talking to its inhabitants. The towns are packed with humor and things to find.

The controls are as tight as they need to be for an action platformer. I played using a 360 pad, and would recommend using a gamepad. After learning new abilities, you will have to combine all your powers to advance in the later stages. I was really amazed at the combinations I could pull off toward the endgame.

I do have one complaint, which falls under performance and controls. Originally it felt like the game moved super fast, and I was having trouble pulling off basic combos and fighting some of the early enemies. One sequence in particular, where you must run in sidescroller fashion from a destructing environment, felt like it was moving way too fast. I was only able to pass it after about 20 attempts. Later I learned that there can be a bug with the vsync that basically doubles the speed of the game. Turning off vsynce solves the problem, however it will lead to some graphical glitches along the way. I found it a small price to pay for a playable game. After playing about the first quarter of the game at double speed, later platforming sections felt pretty easy in comparison.

Beyond my one small complaint above, I was enamored by everything else in Guacamelee. It was fun to explore, fun to see what was next, fun to fight the enemies, and just plain fun overall. I would welcome a sequel, since it feels like there are so many places for this series to go. I see that a rerelease just came out with some new levels, and while I would prefer an entirely new game, eventually I may give that a shot as well.

I completely recommend Guacamelee. While it has received heavy praise so it wasn't a complete surprise, it really exceeded my expectations. At this point you may want to purchase the newer version if you haven't played it yet, but if this game is already sitting in your backlog, move it to the front of the list.

Grade: A

reviewText:
You play as Juan Aguacate, and you're on a quest to save El Presidente's Daughter from the evil skeletal charro; Carlos Calaca.

If you like Metroidvania styled gameplay, look no further. Guacamelee is a game with awesome platforming, the right amount of difficulty, intuitive battle system and has that great hand drawn feel to it. Drinkbox Studios really nailed it with this game. The setting for the game is really unique and the story is so out there it's awesome. There were a few things here and there that I was iffy about in the game, but in my opinion it doesn't take away from the game that much.

Overall, Guacamelee is a solid platformer.

reviewText:
Even if you're not a fan of the Mexican Lucha Libre culture, I would classify this game as a must-buy. With tight controls (I played through it with a keyboard and a controller, with the latter being superior), a nice to look at angular art style and intuitive fighting mechanics this game earned it's place as one of the best Metroidvania games out there.
Guacamelee has Steam workshop support where everyone with experience in Flash can upload their own costumes for the heroes Juan and Tostada.
The only negative aspects I could find were the lackluster story and only one save file. Many gamers fell afoul to the difficulty of the game, and although there are definitely parts considerably harder than others - most of them optional - Drinkbox aimed to appeal to the hardcore gamers.

After getting 100% completion and all achievements you can still perfect your game time/speedrun to earn your place in the leaderboards. For players concerned with replayability, there is lots to do.
You're still reading? If you have the money to shell out, buy and play Guacamelee, the sooner the better!

reviewText:
Guacamelee! Action! Romance! Thrills!

No, really. This game is bloody fantastic, especially when it's not amazingly frustrating.

Core gameplay is solid, simple and to the point. I don't think I've ever had this much fun with a game before. It benefits from a solid, distinct soundtrack, and a pleasing visual art style. This one's for the subscribers of the arts.

When it comes down to the game itself, story is solid, perhaps short, maybe a little spent, but every now and again, a classic hero story is all we need. It's paced accordingly, and catches the eye, and at times, the heart. *sniff*

Combat mechanics are reminiscent of a super watered-down Street Fighter. It's simple, and with practice can become devastating and fast. The upgrades are simple and to the point, just like the rest of the game.

All in all, this is a splendid use of money, as far as games go. It provides hours of fun if you're willing to deal with it, and some serious, but rewarding, challenges. Prepare to curse, though.

NOW GO AND BE GOLDEN.

reviewText:
I used to see this game advertised on Steam and think it couldn't be any good. Boy, was I wrong.

This is truly a little gem. I got it from a humble bundle and decided to try it out just for the hell of it. Ten minutes later, I was hooked. The game plays extremely well, and it's just a LOT of fun. Combat is very satisfying, controls are responsive, artwork is lovely and full of references and humor that'll constantly put a smile on your face.

I started playing with my girlfriend, an aspiring gamer, and Guacamelee proved an immersive, delightful, and easy enough experience (the simple parts at least) that she REALLY enjoyed, and so did I. Even when the game got quite tricky - which it does - and she couldn't help, she stood there, rooting for Juan. Truth be told, we actually ended up going to a mexican restaurant after a playing session, that's how much addicted we were (and still are!) to the whole setting, almost immediately after starting the game.

I also don't think I've ever felt interested enough in getting all the achievements before Guacamelee. They are not too many, and are quite feasible, which I find a very smart strategy: it makes me want to come back again and again after having finished it, instead of putting me off because of the sheer impossibility of completion.

This is one of the best gaming experiences I've ever had.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Very very fine metroidvania with luchador theme. Do not miss this game if you like metroidvania style games at all. The soundtrack is also top-notch mariachi-electro fusion thing and I definitely recommend getting the soundtrack bundle.

In short, Guacamelee is exploration-oriented sidescrolling 2d action game with most gameplay mechanics lifted straight from Super Metroid and refitted with a magical Mexican luchador theme. Suits are wrestling suits and masks, weapons are wrestling moves etc. Even color-coded doors are here and they have to be opened with specific moves. Gamepad is almost mandatory, since you have to be able to control your character quickly and combo all sorts of moves in order to get through some later challenges. The game also features local co-op, where player 2 can just drop in and drop out whenever. I haven't tried it myself, but it should be at least a fun diversion and maybe provide some help in the trickier boss fights.

The game isn't flawless though. The difficulty curve is a bit uneven and especially two of the boss fights provide some nasty difficulty spikes. The fights are far from impossible, but they do require some very good reflexes and good control of all the moves in the player's disposal. Also the game world feels slightly small. Everything is designed quite tightly and there is not too much backtracking, but it feels like there should have been something more. Still, if you feel like 100% the game, the first playthrough should take somewhere in the vicinity of 10-12 hours, so it isn't too short at any rate.

Definitely get this game if you want a good metroidvania and/or love luchadors.

reviewText: Guacamelee caught my interest as soon as it launched on Steam, I still remember that day because on that day Spelunky and Papers, Please were also released on Steam. Having previously played Dust, I think that these two games are very similar yet very different. Guacamelee takes place in a mexican town and tells the story of how you save the world of the living from merging with the world of the dead. I found the graphic style to be really nice and it certainly looks pretty well considering the world in which the game takes place along with the soundtrack which actually made me remember of Total Overdose because it has that very specific latin/mexican feel to it. Now, for me the best part of Guacamelee was the combat, executing combo after combo using different skills and rolling in order to avoid each enemy attack felt really satisfying and that's where I think the game really shines and was probably one of the main reasons why I kept playing it in the first place. Overall I think that if you played games like these, so called metroidvanias"
date: which have alot of backtracking such as Dust An Elysian Tail which I also loved you will certainly have a great time with Guacamelee
recommended: I highly recommend it specially if you enjoy some brawler action yourself
hoursPlayed: either solo or co-op."

reviewText:
Prós:

Excelemente mistura do estilo plataforma com ♥♥♥♥♥daria. Os gráficos 2D estilo vetoriais são de muito bom gosto e cada fase é bem distinta da outra, é um show de cores vivas e bem utilizadas. Em relação a jogabilidade é muito fluida e o combate é divertido e intuitivo. A curva de aprendizado de cada novo poder e dos combos é perfeita.

O game é um mergulho na cultura mexicana, isso é legal, visto que a maioria dos games só explora a cultura americana, inglesa ou japonesa. E o bom humor é presente o tempo todo.

Jogar single player já é bem divertido, a é diversão é muito melhor jogando com outra pessoa ao lado. Pena que o game só dá suporte a coop local, e não online.

Agora vamos aos contras:

- É um game desaconcelhado para quem não curte: games de plataforma, games de ♥♥♥♥♥daria e games bem humorados.
- Os gráficos apesar de bonitos, são limitados e tem poucas cut scenes. E os dialogos são todos feitos por balões de texto, sem dublagem.
- Não possui coop online, somente local.

reviewText: Guacamelee is gorgeous and fun metroidvania game. Reminds me somewhat of Outland, with the switching between light and dark worlds, but Guacamelee has less of the bullet hell and more of the titular melee action. I'm not a huge fan of backtracking, but the world is laid out so smartly that even as it expands, your accumulating powers allow you to traverse the world more and more rapidly. Combat is challenging, but fair. Cetain fight setups felt cheap and unfair on first attempt, but after some careful observation and thought (and a few deaths), they were actually quite reasonable. Checkpoints are relatively generous, and placed in all the spots you'd want them. The boss fight thankfully actually uses the same skills honed during the rest of the game, rather than throwing in something out of left field. All in all, a total pleasure.

reviewText:
The first time I tried playing through this game, I gave up for almost 2 years. I wasn't quite sure why.

I recently retried, because this is a good game and I didn't understand why I disliked it. I did figure out why, though, as I got to a certain mechanic that turned every platforming incident into a timing and reaction dependent stress-fest with massive consequences for failure.

Didn't help that the fighting gets progressively sloppier as you get more combos. I happen to not like combos. Also for some reason, the grappling speeds up as you progress. This makes it harder to do the grappling combos, even though they're simple as hell.

Ultimately, I didn't like the combo based fighting and the platforming turned into an unduly frustrating experience. I think it's actually a good game, still, but I don't like it and I won't recommend it as such. If you like combos and super meat boy platforming, go for it.

reviewText:
I really...really...really want to recommend this game. It's got a great musical score, great artistic style, humor, interesting and seldom-seen-in-a-video-game Mexican-theme. And I've always loved Metroid style games.

** BUT **

The platforming sections of the game are ridiculously difficult. Needlessly difficult, I'd add. I'm still stuck on the section in the Tuli Tree, where you must do a series of wall jumps combined with flipping in and out of the land of death. I cannot do it. And I'm no stranger to platformers!

I wouldn't have a problem with this kind of difficulty if it were only used sparingly in areas of the map with hidden power ups or bonus content. But to make just getting to the next dungeon/temple/castle/level this ludicrously challenging is too much to ask! I play games to be entertained; if the gameplay turns into a repetitive series of failures that's no fun at all!

Part of the problem is that the controller layout isn't ideal. A few glaring control issues: One, Right-Trigger to switch between light and dark worlds!? Bad button mapping! Also, when playing two players, we often accidentally enter the bubble mode, which is disaterous if we both do it at once! And the button placement for chicken mode" isn't so good either. Rather than doding (left trigger) I sometimes bump the left button for Chicken mode. And on top of all that
date: there's no way to re-map the buttons.\n\nSo
recommended: DEV...  before I could recommend this game to anyone
hoursPlayed:
PLEASE fix the level designs and button mapping!


EDIT: I changed my mind on this one. I gave it rest for a while then came back to it. As I had previously said
voteText: it IS insanely hard! But I did finally manage to make more progress. I'm now all the way to boss fight with Calaca! It's definitely a good game

reviewText: Captivating action platformer. The humorous mexican theme is well done, and the dual world concept provides a nice touch to the gameplay. The actual fighting with combos and special moves is enjoyable, and the gradual difficulty increase will not have you hitting a wall early in the game.\nThat being said, as the game progresses there are points where you will have to pull off some tricky moves to make progress, but don't give up. They are easier than it seems at first and generally rewarding with frequent checkpoints, steady progress and achievements.

reviewText: Old school beat-'em-up with strong, STRONG overtones of metroidvania style gameplay and backtracking. Generally speaking it's loads of fun and it looks absolutely gorgeous because the aesthetic is drenched in mexican culture, primarily the Dios de las Muertos. The only downsides are it basically requires you to have a controller as some of the later fights are damn  near impossible with keyboard controls alone. There are also some extremely demanding platforming/jump timing sections in order to get life/stamina expansions that are possible to get early on but are so incredibly difficult to do so that you'll likely end up saying Screw it
date: I'll come back later" and when you do with later upgrades you'll find them to be incredibly easy. Overall one of the best metroidvania games on steam and unquestionably one of the most stylish. If you have a controller to use with your PC then I can't recommend this enough
recommended: if not you may want to give this a pass. 8/10"

reviewText:
Guacamelee makes very fine use of its life/afterlife-switching mechanic and special moves for some very enjoyable platforming. Those two, along with its grappling-and-throwing-based combat system, consistently keep encounters interesting.

The visual style and the music are very memorable as well, and some of the antagonists are actually good characters in their own right.

Now, if only the developers hadn't gone overboard with the meme references...

reviewText: Hmm, where do I start? There's a whole lot to say. I've never been into platforming, but after completing this game, I've found out that I really like the platforming genre which means I'm going to end up buying more games like this in the future. Anyways, over to the review. Guacamelee is and has everything that all platformers should be/have. Drinkbox Studios have been able to mix the platforming itself, exploration and combat along with each other perfectly. A reason alone to buy this game if you're into platforming is all the funny and immature comments all the different npcs, placed in the world has to say. Besides, who doesn't want to run 'round in Mexico as the great Luchador, beating up silly enemies while listening to mariachi backgroundmusic. It's been tons of fun completing this game and if you're on the edge of buying Guacamelee; You sure have my recommendation.

reviewText:
Guacamelee! is a fantastic game.

I haven't been so enthralled with a game since Super Mario Bros. It's family - friendly, looks good, sounds great, the concept is fresh, and an entertaining challenge. Supports co-op, gamepads, and has Workshop features.

Haven't completed the game as of this writing, but i've been enamored with what i've played so far. The game has an opened combat system and encourages exploration, so I feel once I've finished I won't mind playing again and again on ocassion. reviewText: Guacamelee! is an action-platformer with a strong emphasis on combat. The fighting mechanics are easy to pick up right a way, but still deep enough to remain interesting. This combined with a dimension-switching mechanic makes for one hell of a platformer! The humour in the game was also spot on for me. reviewText:
Intro:TLDR: Gameplay: Outstanding!  -  Visuals: Stunningly beautiful artstyle -  Story: Fitting  -  Coop: Double the fun, though making the game easier at some points.  -  9/10

Amazing 2D sidescroller with a very broad combat system! Boss-battles, mini-bosses, loads of different enemies, platforming, jump-puzzles with various difficulties, and a great storyline. A Masterpeice! If you like a challanging platformer/combat-sidescroller; this is it for you.

Originally got this game through a HumbleBundle and wasen't expecting much from it. Boy was I in for a surprise!

Pros and Cons:++ Pros:
+ Local coop
+ Responsive controls
+ Full controller support
+ Combat with a lot of variations
+ Customizations
+ Fun and fine story
+ Side-material (and loads of it)
+ Immersive world
+ Artstyle

- - Cons:
- Fairly short actual story
- Coop restricted to local

Details:The games features a coop mode, but this is however only on a local pc. The coop mode is essentialy adding another character to the game with next to none extra interactions. This is however a neat feature for the game, and is very fun. doubles the people, double the fun, right!? right indeed.

The combat and movement system is extremely good, you control every action, and your charactor is a super responsive slave to your controller of choice. It features full controller support, which I personally find great for this kind of game. Great use of combo variation and at some points it is even a necesity to win a duel or complete a challange.

Wether you jump your way thorugh spikes, traps and platforms, or (Guaca)melee your way through hazzards of enemies, It's allways a very good mixtures of the two main gameplay mechanics. The game has a lot of mechnics, which are all very well explained, and it forces you to utilizes almost everyone of them. You can't just stomp thorugh the game using one move, or one combat technique. Variation is key to defeat certain enemies.

One word *Sidematerial*!!! Side-quests (so to speak), challange modes, collectiables, unlockables. Guacamelee has pretty much all of it. It also featues a some custimization to suit your playstyle as well. Some of the challanges may be difficult and frustratin! I must admit I at one point spent 1½ hours completing a single jump-puzzle... I suck... damn my stubborness. And yet other parts may be a peice of cake.

The overall game is an eye-pleaser. The artline is amazing, especially considering it being a just" a 2D sidescroller. You can really feel the mood of the game
date: being pumped up with references to other games
recommended: memes and various sidestories. It's all in the detail of the tiny thing. And there is a lot of tiny things in this game. Makes for an overall better experience. It is very rewarding to go around exploring the world of guacamelee
hoursPlayed: trust me on this one!\n\nThe story is pretty straight-forward
voteText: humorous
helpfulPercent: filled with some unique characters. This is however not the bearing factor
votesHelpful: as it falls a bit short compared to the standard of the other parts of the game. Only problem is that you can rush through the main storyline in a matter of a few hours
votesTotal:
which leaves you storywise a bit dissatisfied. The loads of extra content largely outweights this problem though.

Final verdict:One of the best sidescrolles i've ever played. Rewarding to play.
"Me Gusta". I rate this game 9/10."

reviewText: Knowing nothing about this game before playing it, it completely took me by surprise -- and a pleasant one it was!  I was immediately hooked by its excellent soundtrack and crisp visuals.  It didn't take long for me to find myself immersed in a combat system that finds the perfect balance between control and chaos, interspersed with platforming sections that require both brains and lightning-fast reflexes to conquer.  Guacamelee definitely feels like a game made by people who knew what made games fun 15-20 years ago, as I often found myself comparing it to games like Tomba, Castlevania: SotN, and even Soul Reaver.  Highly recommended!

reviewText:
Overall, this game is pretty alright. Not very long by this genre's standards, but it's still a good 9-10 hours if you want to do everything. I'd give it a solid 8/10, but something bugs me.

Hard mode is complete and utter trash. I don't usually complain about hard difficulties, hell, I love hard difficulties, but this game wanted to be special. You want a hard mode that smooths out the game's uneven difficulty? ♥♥♥♥ you! Instead, you get a game with even worse difficulty jumps, horribly unbalanced enemy combinations, and a game that, honestly, isn't very entertaining on a second playthrough.

But hey, if that's your thing, go right ahead hombre. The game is fun enough on its initial playthrough to warrant the $3.75 price tag I bought it at.

6/10

reviewText:
Do you like quick melee sidescrolling combat and adventure (and tacos). Then you'll love Guacamelee! This Mexican themed action platformer is set in in the colourful world of luchadores and the not-so-colourful world of the dead (which is still nice to look at anyway). The fighting is fast paced with plenty of moves and enemies to mix it up. There are also puzzle solving elements, where the player (that's you!) has to utilise the new techniques you have learned and quick reactions to solve them all. The music is also beautifully well suited, as are all the sound effects.

The game can be a bit challenging at times when you're facing multiple enemies in different dimensions, but by no means is it impossible. There is a hard mode available after completion of the game if you found the first run through too easy.

The game however, is quite short unfortunately. I finished it in 5:15, though that was with completing most all of the puzzles along the way (which probably made it easier for me anyway). That said, there are a number of side quests that I did not complete, and with multiple costumes also available, combined with the hard mode, there is some replayability in this game.

Another feature, though I have not tried it out, is co-op mode. Could be fun, but not necessary anyway.

The story isn't too bad - typical save the princess stuff with a Mexican and underworld theme mixed into it. The dialogue can be funny at times, but I think the only decent material was when references to other games were made. I feel like the developers tried too hard with this, and perhaps should have been more subtle most of the time - to me it seems they relied upon it too much.

Guacamelee is fun, beautiful to look at, and engrossing, which is why I recommend it, but considering it's length, I would wait for a sale so as to get more bang for your buck.

reviewText:
This game honestly surprised me. At first, it looks and feels just like any indie Metroidvania game. However, Guacamelee is actually extremely polished and the control scheme is one of the best I've ever seen (using an x360 controller).

The game offers a ton of fun and unique mechanics, solid combat and all the usual maps to explore and bosses to fight, pretty much what you can expect from a solid platformer. all done with very cute graphics and a cheerful soundtrack. This gives Guacamelee a certain sense of lightheartedness, despite getting quite difficult at times.

After the main storyline, there's still more to do; a hard mode that makes the combat a bit more challenging, and optional challenge rooms in the Infierno, which will put your platforming, creativity and reaction skills to the test.
Definitely my game of the year.

reviewText: A surprisingly solid platformer. I love the visual style and the countless video game references are pretty funny. While it is a bit too short story wise, it has a lot of secrets to discover, and the well designed levels are an encouragement to explore. If you want to get 100% with a good ending, get ready to suffer as some of the challenges, platform puzzles in particular, are ridiculously unforgiving. reviewText:
You probably have a good idea of what Guacamelee is by now. A Metroidvania with a Mexican Wrestler/Luchador theme, where the stamina-draining moves you learn are what unlock new areas. This is mainly done through colored blocks that require a specific skill in order to be broken. And that's the extent of the Metroidvania.
It's simple enough and proves to be a lot of fun in the largest portion of the game.

However, several things in the end come together to create a frustrating experience unless you're the sort of player who's perfectly accustomed to every trick in the brawler book. And in fact, die-hard brawler fans are the only people I would really recommend this game to, at least to completion.

In the near-end game, you run into enemies and a few bosses that like to 'shield' themselves. A bubble fitting their shape that can only be broken by a specific stamina attack, which uses the same color coding as the aforementioned blocks. This actually starts out as a great idea as it throws around the way you think and need to approach a combat situation.
But therein lies the first problem: The 'yellow' attack, being headbutt, requires you to stand still and press the B button (on the controller).

However, it takes about half a second before the game apparently registers you standing still, meaning you're spamming B while nothing happens but you standing there.
Obviously, in a high pace brawler, this means you are immediately punished for it by being attacked.
This headbutt lag only becomes more frustrating when you are going up against bosses that constantly change their type of shield. So whenever headbutt is required, you can count on it that you are going to get punished for it. It requires a compensation the likes where you feel like you are compensating for a bug.

Another technique that you must master in order to progress is the art of blocking. In the beginning, that's only required to jump through thorn vines. But eventually you will run into situations where the amount of melee and ranged enemies make it short of change of perspective to make it a bullet hell. Blocking is essential, period.
And this is where another problem sets in. As someone trained by 'Witch time' in Bayonetta, I expect my blocking in a brawler to be instant. Many are the times where I had blocked a moment before being hit, yet it did not register. Frustrating.

But the biggest issue are the 'gauntlets' you are forced to partake in. These are single rooms where you are shut in and are forced to beat all the enemies that spawn. Most of the time these are pretty fun, if not challenging. But every now and then you find a gauntlet that simply does not belong in the game. In one, you were forced to constantly pop the appearing timed 'balloons' because otherwise, upon exploding, you receive significant damage. In the middle is an obstruction that has a hazard on top. And the balloons constantly appear on opposite sides of the room, AND you have to deal with other spawning enemies. Meaning you not only have to run like mad at each timed balloon, but you need to dodge any other ranged attacks and then survive the other enemies.

One other that I vividly remember is being forced to fight enemies that like to throw columns of light at you, and for some reason their AI likes to constantly throw these in sync where the distance between both columns is too great to overcome with one dodge/block, meaning you get hit regardless. But the biggest sinner is the gauntlet is the one where you have to kill a series of instakill exploding balloons with the moves they're obviously lined up for. But this brings another shortcoming: The special moves have a deceptively shorter range than they appear to have.

But my biggest gripe with these gauntlets is that they are non-optional. You have to do them, no matter how ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t they are. There's no going around them, meaning you have to suffer their punishment for as long as it takes for you to master whatever (usually pointless) lesson it wants to impart. Because I can guarantee you, most lessons you will take from these will not help in boss battles.

Not to mention that the throwing-invincibility frames are deceptive as well, there's no telling in a split second when you are vulnerable at the end of your throw. Yet at the final boss, this is exactly whats required to know.
All in all, the game likes to maximise the abuse out of your weakness, even when they are being forced on you by the game itself. It's unfair and harsh and maybe that's why it's not the sort of game for me. I can take difficult games, very difficult games. Games like Bayonetta (when going for Platinum), Super Meat Boy (A+'ing everything) and Ninja Gaiden (because, game) all are enjoyable for me because their responsiveness is perfect. Any mistake you make in those games are your fault alone. Failing because of an uncontrollable contender, however, makes for something very frustrating. Which is exactly the thing this game sins to.

Storywise... it's cheesy. But what do you expect? The game itself likes throwing joke after joke at you, referencing many things that are Gaming related. It doesn't take itself too serious and neither should you. It's okay.
But with me having a bunch of frustrations with this game, I can't get myself to collect the other hidden mask pieces for the 'Good' ending or even replay the game.

Yes, I have to say the game is pretty good at what it's trying to do. Nowhere near the best, especially with me having so many irks around responsiveness. But if you can get over the gripes I have (or somehow manage to not experience them at all as a rare few do) then yeah... maybe you'll enjoy it. It won't be easy, even on Normal, so make sure you bring some alcohol to mellow you out. Because this game won't let you off the hook that easy.

reviewText: Guacamelee! is very much not shy about being a Metroidvania, but it still is a great standalone game with its own unique mechanics that are gradually introduced and it comes naturally using them to solve puzzles. The combat is great, and I enjoyed every fight, even if the final boss was a big and somewhat frustrating ramp up in difficulty I managed to defeat him in one sitting. It is also just a well written lighthearted game, as I feel it should be, aside from a couple moments. The visuals are bright and colorful, and the music is good too.\nBut where this game really shines, is when you have unlocked many of the powers and have to use them all in combination to get through some of the later platforming sections. They're used in truly brilliant ways here. Although sometimes I felt it could have gone further, it was just a lot of fun getting through the last few areas. It helps that falling does not kill or even hurt you. Of course colliding with a thorny vine or some spikes or an enemy's attack still will, so it's not as if there's no risk.\nOverall, this game surprised me with how well made it was. Now I was expecting a decent game, but this was great. I played it whenever I could.

reviewText: Guacamelee although short (6-8 hours) and somewhat easy, is a really fun metroidvania style brawler. As you progress you unlock combos and special moves and experience a ton of ridiculous scenarios (the humor is brilliant). There are tons of unlockables and a hard mode if you choose to play through a second time. The moves are pretty creative and don't feel all that gimicky or hard to utilize. I stuck with a gamepad the whole way through and the controls felt really solid. Also, co-op makes the game 100 times better; I definitely recommend playing with a friend.

reviewText:
This is my first review. It’s for a game that really deserves the effort. Guacamelee. It tells a classical story in which you (Juan, a former agave farmer and now luchador) have to save “El Presidente’s Daughter” from the evil charro Carlos Calaca.

The game features a mix of platforming, combat and exploration. You start with a few basic moves and learn better ones throughout the game. Juan is able to switch between the two worlds of the living and the dead. This also changes music and environment. Both are brilliant and you will discover many details and references to other games.

One of the best parts of the game are no doubt the dialogs. They are hilarious and contain many Spanish words. I don’t know the Spanish language but had no problems understanding everything. I think I might have missed a few jokes but that’s ok. For the first time, while playing the game at home alone, I read out aloud every dialog. They are fantastic.

It took me about 6 hours to finish the game. The difficulty is appropriate on normal. If you get the chance to play this game make sure you don’t miss it. I had great fun playing it! Enjoy!

reviewText:
I'll let you in on a little secret: my favourite game is Metroid Prime. Prime 2 and 3 probably rank second and third respectively, but before I get longwinded: I love Metroid games.

As such I also have the poor habit of buying Super Metroid every time Nintendo rehashes it just to get some more of that sweet exploration action. Consequentially, I also love the Castlevania series...basically for being Metroid. Enter Guacamelee, an indie game that basically is Metroidvania, but dipped in taco sauce and smothered in chili's. You are Juan, a agave farmer who one day finds his town in peril and recovers a mask that gives him mystic Luchador powers. Along the way he learns new moves from peculiar looking statues and supplexes baddies into the ground to save the woman he, supposedly, loves. I don't know, the game doesn't care much about the whole love story. It wants you to play Metroid. And it does. Really well. In fact, the number of references to Metroid (and any other game for that matter) are so abundant, you might consider the developers lazy for not trying harder themselves.

I'm poking holes now, cause Guacamelee is hilarious and fast and it certainly is excellent while it lasts. It channels that old-school spirit very well. Ugh, now I want to play some more Metroid.

reviewText:
This game is disturbingly overlooked... It's like a entertaining luchadore-inspired Mexican yarn complete with switching between the real world and the tierra de los muertos (on the fly once you beat the first boss) with solid beat-em-up action. And an ungodly amount of pop culture references. Expect to see Strong Bad, Mega Man, Metroid references, Link (Zelda series), troll faces, sriracha references, and who knows how much more...

And oh god, the soundtrack... Most all the tracks are done in a true Mariachi style, with horns and acoustic guitar.

Seriously, buy this game if you like beat-em-ups or humor. And if you want a darn good deal, Humble Bundle's got it in their 11th bundle right now with 3 other games.

Not to mention that the throwing-invincibility frames are deceptive as well, there's no telling in a split second when you are vulnerable at the end of your throw. Yet at the final boss, this is exactly whats required to know.
All in all, the game likes to maximise the abuse out of your weakness, even when they are being forced on you by the game itself. It's unfair and harsh and maybe that's why it's not the sort of game for me. I can take difficult games, very difficult games. Games like Bayonetta (when going for Platinum), Super Meat Boy (A+'ing everything) and Ninja Gaiden (because, game) all are enjoyable for me because their responsiveness is perfect. Any mistake you make in those games are your fault alone. Failing because of an uncontrollable contender, however, makes for something very frustrating. Which is exactly the thing this game sins to.

Storywise... it's cheesy. But what do you expect? The game itself likes throwing joke after joke at you, referencing many things that are Gaming related. It doesn't take itself too serious and neither should you. It's okay.
But with me having a bunch of frustrations with this game, I can't get myself to collect the other hidden mask pieces for the 'Good' ending or even replay the game.

Yes, I have to say the game is pretty good at what it's trying to do. Nowhere near the best, especially with me having so many irks around responsiveness. But if you can get over the gripes I have (or somehow manage to not experience them at all as a rare few do) then yeah... maybe you'll enjoy it. It won't be easy, even on Normal, so make sure you bring some alcohol to mellow you out. Because this game won't let you off the hook that easy.

reviewText:
This is easily one of the most engaging games I've seen on the market. Up front, the journey to 100% the game can be infuriating at times, but the casual playthrough is filled with interesting platforming, just enough mechanics to avoid being cumbersome or confusing, a striking art style and presentation, and a comedic style in the dialogue.

The game never seems to drop mechanics it introduces. Many games will put a mechanic on display for one or two stages. Not so with Guacamelee! Throughout the game, the designers constantly throw both old and new at you. It even has things for the hardcore audience with a particular attention to speedrunning.

Things I would have liked to see

1. Tighter input reading: I felt like the game responded slightly late on my button presses at times, though this could be atttributed to my monitor not being top of the line in latency.

2. Controller editting: It seems like a huge oversight in a game this polished for you to be unable to assign any controller button to any action.

reviewText: Great Metroid-style fantasy platformer with a focus on luchadore melee-fighting action. Amazing, fluid cartoon-inspired art. Makes great use out of all the learned special moves and mechanics, great combo system, very smooth controls and inspired level design. Perfect length, so the game finished before any of it gets old. Lots of references for gamers, both in art assets and in the design of the game. Blatantly steals a lot, but lampshades it to a point where you'd feel a bit cynical to complain. Play it.

reviewText:
I uninstalled this game in disgust!, BUT I'd still recommend it.

I uninstalled Guacamelee Gold! because the game became entirely about complicated wall jumping combined with phase transitions, and that just ceased to be fun for me after several progressions in challenge difficulty.  After looking ahead on YouTube to see how much more jumping I was in for, I got the feeling that, if I practiced enough, I probably could have eventually pulled the sequences off, but no thanks.  After one last time of getting near the end of a long jump sequence only to miss the last button, I sighed and uninstalled the game.  I'll own that, but I'll also put some blame on the controller mapping, which doesn't seem to be editable, at least with a 360 controller on the PC.

I'd still recommend the game because it has a truly excellent sense of style: great art, great humor, great animation, etc.  For a few bucks I think that's worth it even if you don't get to the end.  I also recommend it because maybe wall jumping is your thing if so, jump away sweet prince(cess).

reviewText:
Metroidvania at it's finest, mixed with crazy platforming moments.

Amazing art-style, and crisp hd vector graphics; very skewed towards mexican folklore, so it is clearly not for everyone. Plagued (literally) with references to other games and internet culture.
The atention to detail it's remarkable, without any copy and paste material, or mirrored levels, a problem that plagues the genre, ie: the last nds Castlevania iteration. This gives really fresh content for the entire game, but it comes at a price, the length of it.
The length is little short for any major genre enthusiast, with just a little obvious backtracking here and there.
The game copes with this by presenting you with amazingly difficult platforming challenges, mixed with insta-death and insta-respawn.
I assure you that 2 sections of this game will get you stuck jumping the same platforms again and again for about an hour. For me that sounds like fun, been an old gamer from the NES era, but i am sure that many new fellas will feel ripped off by the platforming difficulty of this title. Some of this rooms are just for item-grabbing, but others are mandatory and un-skippable.
Go watch some youtube vids of it, to get an idea
Another thing to mention is the combat system. This game hides an amazingly complex and robust combo system, that you can learn through the game, and test in the Hell challenges.


It took me about 11 hours in my first run, and then about 4 on my second run.

reviewText:
This game is disturbingly overlooked... It's like a entertaining luchadore-inspired Mexican yarn complete with switching between the real world and the tierra de los muertos (on the fly once you beat the first boss) with solid beat-em-up action. And an ungodly amount of pop culture references. Expect to see Strong Bad, Mega Man, Metroid references, Link (Zelda series), troll faces, sriracha references, and who knows how much more...

And oh god, the soundtrack... Most all the tracks are done in a true Mariachi style, with horns and acoustic guitar.

Seriously, buy this game if you like beat-em-ups or humor. And if you want a darn good deal, Humble Bundle's got it in their 11th bundle right now with 3 other games.

reviewText:
Guacamelee! is a Mexican-themed beat em’ up platformer with puzzle solving elements and a very silly sense of humor. I don’t usually dig beat em’ up games, but I’m glad checked this game out, it’s pretty awesome. You play as Juan Aguacate, a Mexican farmer who dons a magical luchador mask to become a superpowered wrestler in order to save his kidnapped girlfriend.

The game can be played solo or co-op, a second player can assume the role of the female wrestler “Tostada”. I played through the game both solo and co-op. The co-op makes the platforming sections a bit more frantic, but makes the beat em’ up sections and boss fights quite a bit easier.

The game has some Metroidvania elements as well: as you progress through the game and unlock new wrestling moves, you’ll gain access to areas you previously unable to reach. As mentioned before, Guacamelee! also has a very silly sense of humor. It’s chock full of “nerd jokes”, internet humor and direct references to other video games. It was kind of a fun “can you spot them all?” subgame within Guacamelee!; trying to catch some of the more subtle video game references. There was even a Zelda II reference in there! How many people are really going to get that one?

Guacamelee! is a bit on the short side, but it’s quite good. Check it out.

For more game reviews, check out http://whatisjamesplaying.blogspot.com/
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: SO GOOD. So ♥♥♥♥ing colourful and pretty I want to cry. And fun. The references! The music! The style! Being a blue female spirit named Tostada and despite that still being called Juan and seen as a man! (That's not like, a feature... It just doesn't matter if you're wearing the Juan costume or the Tostada one, you're still Juan, and it's funny [let me be, ok]). It is a great platformer/action/adventure game, quite addictive and dynamic, and I had no idea I would like it this much. I thought it would be some kind of boring hack'n'slash (I should have probably read the description or something) but I'm enjoying it a lot. A LOT. Buy it.

reviewText:
This is a tight, well-tuned metroidvania with spectacle fighter beat-em'-up combat. The combat scales from the trivial to the relentless:
- Some attacks can be dodged, others cannot.
- Enemies can be shielded with barriers that make them invulnerable until one of four specific attacks is used against them, or until they are pummeled with several attacks quickly.
- Enemies can be in either the land of the dead or the land of the living. They can attack you from either but you can only attack them if you're in the same world as them.

But you have several tools to outmaneuver them:
- Daze your enemies and then smash them around with wrestling throws to use them as projectiles or area-stun effects.
- Four distinct special attacks that launch you or your enemies in different directions.
- Turn in to a chicken and peck the bejebus out of your enemies to rack up higher combos.
- Freely phase between the living world and the land of the dead.
- Dodge through enemy attacks to rack your combos higher and negate damage.
- Lock enemies in aerial combos for a moment's respite from the earth.
- Unlock outfits with special powers.

If the game was only a beat-em'-up it would still be nearly worth the price of admission - but the various combat tools you attain are also the methods by which you unlock additional areas to traverse. The game strongly rewards exploration with both practical benefits (more life and more whuppin' fuel) and significant soft benefits (a better ending than the default for finding five main secrets).

All of this is backed by a crisp sense of humor, good writing, and a consistent mythology based in incan myth and mexican folklore. Critically, the controls are very tight - at least with an XBox 360 controller, which I had - which allows you to play with confidence that it won't glitch you out. If you have interest in metroidvania's or spectacle fighters, Guacamelee is well worth your time.

reviewText:
This game is possibly one of the best 2D platformers I've ever played. It's a hard game, but not too hard, well......not on levels used in order to advance the story anyways. There are several hardcore levels in this game, but they are mainly for side-quests like collecting all the orbs or the Inferno challenges. But otherwise, the difficulty is pretty fair.

The graphics are really nice-looking and stylish, even if the characters and monsters are Flash-animated, the Mexican-themed art-style is what made this game so gorgeous. The music is astoundishing and the trumpets and guitar fits perfectly with this game's environment.

But what really makes this game shine is the gameplay. It has the style of a Metroidvania platformer mixed in with a beat-em-up. You perform different kinds of combos to beat up your enemies with and can add them up together much like a 2D fighter game. The game has plenty of areas to explore in, lots of side-quests to accomplish, and even has it's own arenas if you're interested in completing the game 100%.

My only downside is the story, which isn't anything new and intriguing, and is pretty straightforward. Other than that, I highly recommend this game to anyone that loves 2D side-scrollers and loves to explore.

reviewText:
Overall, this game is pretty alright. Not very long by this genre's standards, but it's still a good 9-10 hours if you want to do everything. I'd give it a solid 8/10, but something bugs me.

Hard mode is complete and utter trash. I don't usually complain about hard difficulties, hell, I love hard difficulties, but this game wanted to be special. You want a hard mode that smooths out the game's uneven difficulty? ♥♥♥♥ you! Instead, you get a game with even worse difficulty jumps, horribly unbalanced enemy combinations, and a game that, honestly, isn't very entertaining on a second playthrough.

But hey, if that's your thing, go right ahead hombre. The game is fun enough on its initial playthrough to warrant the $3.75 price tag I bought it at.

6/10

reviewText:
In this game you play as Juan, an agave farmer (not avacado). His childhood love comes back to town from college and then ♥♥♥♥ hits the fan when Carlos Calcala comes from the land of the dead to invade your world. He takes your love and then kills you. You are ressurected with a magical luchador mask.

Pros
Great exploration for completionists
Great fighting (if you think Batman games have good fighitng you are dead wrong)
Great villian.
It's funny!

Cons
Platforming sections that make you switch between dimensions (you gotta have a good reaction time but don't worry you'll get it eventually) I still felt it slowed down the gameplay.
No Guacamole

People say it's short but you can't say that if you haven't beaten El Inferno challenges or found all the items (most of them at least). Or if you haven't beaten hard mode (I have yet to play). My point is that you can say you've played a game but you don't really play it. Guacameele is very fun and solid and makes you come back for more.

reviewText:
I absolutely love this game, buy it now!

That being said, this is a really intelligent, polished and fun metroidvania game. Metroidvania is probably my favorite video game genre, and this one gets it right. While the game doesn't have a large focus on exploration, its still there. The combat is legitimately fun, and is not just tacked on like in many games of the genre. The platforming sections are very interesting and can get challenging. The atmosphere and setting are very unique and cool. The music is beautiful and fitting. The humor is quite good, I laughed out loud a good deal at some of this game's jokes.

I think the coolest thing about this game is the way that platforming and combat are integrated. As you progress in the game you gain combat moves, powerful punches and such. These moves are used in combat, but also are the backbone of platforming. For example the first move you learn is an uppercut that launches you upwards in the air. And while useful for combatting enemies and sending them skyward, the uppercut can also be used as a double jump" of sorts.

Highly

reviewText: Guacamelee although short (6-8 hours) and somewhat easy, is a really fun metroidvania style brawler. As you progress you unlock combos and special moves and experience a ton of ridiculous scenarios (the humor is brilliant). There are tons of unlockables and a hard mode if you choose to play through a second time. The moves are pretty creative and don't feel all that gimicky or hard to utilize. reviewText:
Guacamelee! is a Mexican-themed beat em’ up platformer with puzzle solving elements and a very silly sense of humor. I don’t usually dig beat em’ up games, but I’m glad checked this game out, it’s pretty awesome. You play as Juan Aguacate, a Mexican farmer who dons a magical luchador mask to become a superpowered wrestler in order to save his kidnapped girlfriend.

The game can be played solo or co-op, a second player can assume the role of the female wrestler “Tostada”. I played through the game both solo and co-op. The co-op makes the platforming sections a bit more frantic, but makes the beat em’ up sections and boss fights quite a bit easier.

The game has some Metroidvania elements as well: as you progress through the game and unlock new wrestling moves, you’ll gain access to areas you previously unable to reach. As mentioned before, Guacamelee! also has a very silly sense of humor. It’s chock full of “nerd jokes”, internet humor and direct references to other video games. It was kind of a fun “can you spot them all?” subgame within Guacamelee!; trying to catch some of the more subtle video game references. There was even a Zelda II reference in there! How many people are really going to get that one?

Guacamelee! is a bit on the short side, but it’s quite good. Check it out.

For more game reviews, check out http://whatisjamesplaying.blogspot.com/

reviewText:
Metroidvania at it's finest, mixed with crazy platforming moments.

Amazing art-style, and crisp hd vector graphics; very skewed towards mexican folklore, so it is clearly not for everyone. Plagued (literally) with references to other games and internet culture.
The atention to detail it's remarkable, without any copy and paste material, or mirrored levels, a problem that plagues the genre, ie: the last nds Castlevania iteration. This gives really fresh content for the entire game, but it comes at a price, the length of it.
The length is little short for any major genre enthusiast, with just a little obvious backtracking here and there.
The game copes with this by presenting you with amazingly difficult platforming challenges, mixed with insta-death and insta-respawn.
I assure you that 2 sections of this game will get you stuck jumping the same platforms again and again for about an hour. For me that sounds like fun, been an old gamer from the NES era, but i am sure that many new fellas will feel ripped off by the platforming difficulty of this title. Some of this rooms are just for item-grabbing, but others are mandatory and un-skippable.
Go watch some youtube vids of it, to get an idea
Another thing to mention is the combat system. This game hides an amazingly complex and robust combo system, that you can learn through the game, and test in the Hell challenges.


It took me about 11 hours in my first run, and then about 4 on my second run.

reviewText:
Guacamelee is a Metroidvania style (i'd say maybe a light variation though, as it features no backtracking) game that lets you play a farmer turned luchadore, back from the realm of the dead to save to world. You fight about 15-ish different enemies, learn various special attacks which also offer movement tricks required for some platforming elements in this game. The last key feature is that you can switch between the realm of the living and the dead. You'll have to use the world shift as well as the special moves to deal with your enemies, who can attack from both planes of existence while also being protected by some form of shield that requires a particular attack to break first.

Personally I liked the graphic style, but I can see that it might be offputting for others. I did experience a graphical bug that caused a very particular form of screen-tearing, regardless of Vsync options.

I found the combat pretty satisfying, and I can say that a controller is required to get the best experience possible.

The game isn't all that long; It takes about 6.5 hours to complete a playthough to start to finish, solo (the game support Co-Op, but I haven't tried it) on Normal. It offers some challenge modes and harder difficulties, as well as speedrun leaderboards, in case that's your cup of tea. Definately get it when it's on sale!

reviewText:
I love metroidvania games, ever since I first played an import copy of Symphony of the Night way back when, and I've played every Castlevania or other major title in the genre since. I don't think I'm exaggerating when I say that Guacamelee is one of the very best games the genre has ever seen.

The game really has everything; excellent graphics with a healthy serving of style, wonderful music, tight and well-executed controls and combat and a world that's simply fun to explore. That's really the key word here; this game is FUN! Everything from juggling enemies and racking up a 300 hit combo to exploring every nook and cranny of the world is constantly and consistently engaging and entertaining.

The game also keeps things fresh by throwing a curveball or two your way, mostly in the shape of balls-hard platforming segments, almost on the level of something like Super Meat Boy. This is actually something I think the game does well, because most entries in this genre have pretty uninteresting and frankly lame platforming, Castlevania included. Guacamelee wears its platform roots on its sleeve and demands some tricky, technical jumping from you, and it's all the better for it.

As you can see, I have nothing but praise for this game. I could ramble on about how much I love it all day, so I'm just going to summarize and say that if you have any interest in this genre and haven't played this game yet, you absolutely have to. Like right now. Do not pass go, do not wait for a sale; play it immediately!

reviewText:
Easily one of the best indie games i've ever purchased.  If an action platformer, a beat em up, and metroidvania had a child this would be the child.  In this game you fight and grapple the enemies, as well as using moves you unlock throughout the games.  All of your moves can combo together.  For example, I can use my upward punch, then jump up and rooster claw(upward attack that shoots you up too.  This is useful all game to help you platform as well.), attack them multiple times, then either groundpound them, headbutt them away, or grapple them and follow up with one of my throws.  I could always piledrive my enemy, kick them 20 feet away, or do a deadly suplex to help wipe out the enemies that might await below me.

The enemies have a good variety, even tho I wish it had more.   I felt like with a little more variety amongst the enemies, this game would have been so much more fun.

For now, I'll give it a 8.5/10.  I truly recommend this gem of a game, on sale or off.

Honestly, can't reccomend this game enough.

reviewText:
Guacamelee is a well rounded game with challenging platforming and a satisfying combat system. The soundtrack, artwork, and in particular the animation are all pleasant and cohesive.

Combat is intuitive and flowing, and Guacamelee does a good job of forcing you to use your full range of powers by the variety of enemies and their weaknesses. The abilities you acquire find use both in combat and in platforming/exploration, so you end up really looking forward to discovering the next powerup.

The local co-op mode works well during the fighting sections; flinging a hapless enemy across the screen to your partner who then slams them into the ground doesn’t get old. Unfortunately, the co-op platforming is a mess. The sections that use the environment-shifting mechanic are great fun in single player, but in co-op it's impossible not to get in each others' way. On top of that, the camera essentially only follows one player, which means it is inevitably more efficient to just let one player attempt the jumps while the other player watches.

Guacamelee’s smooth animations, upbeat soundtrack, colourful backgrounds and enjoyable Luchador theme all contribute to a polished feel. Other than the weak co-op I don’t have any major complaints. I wasn't blown away but I definitely enjoyed my time with it. Recommended for fans of metroidvania games, worth a look for everyone else.

reviewText: I didn't even know what this game was as it came inside a bundle with another game I was looking to try (which by the way I haven't played yet, after learning what this game was about). Eventually I tried to complete as much as possible but then I just said eff it on some of the inferno challenges, this game is better suited for 10 year olds with super fast reflexes than old timers like me. Regarless I still recommend if you have some patience and love sidescrolling adventures in the vein of Metroid and Castlevania.\n\nPS. there are a lot of hilarious game references in this game, i must have seen at least 10 some blatent and others hiding in the background.

reviewText:
Guacamelee is a Metroidvania style (i'd say maybe a light variation though, as it features no backtracking) game that lets you play a farmer turned luchadore, back from the realm of the dead to save to world. You fight about 15-ish different enemies, learn various special attacks which also offer movement tricks required for some platforming elements in this game. The last key feature is that you can switch between the realm of the living and the dead. You'll have to use the world shift as well as the special moves to deal with your enemies, who can attack from both planes of existence while also being protected by some form of shield that requires a particular attack to break first.

Personally I liked the graphic style, but I can see that it might be offputting for others. I did experience a graphical bug that caused a very particular form of screen-tearing, regardless of Vsync options.

I found the combat pretty satisfying, and I can say that a controller is required to get the best experience possible.

The game isn't all that long; It takes about 6.5 hours to complete a playthough to start to finish, solo (the game support Co-Op, but I haven't tried it) on Normal. It offers some challenge modes and harder difficulties, as well as speedrun leaderboards, in case that's your cup of tea. Definately get it when it's on sale!

reviewText:
Intro:TLDR: Gameplay: Outstanding!  -  Visuals: Stunningly beautiful artstyle -  Story: Fitting  -  Coop: Double the fun, though making the game easier at some points.  -  9/10

Amazing 2D sidescroller with a very broad combat system! Boss-battles, mini-bosses, loads of different enemies, platforming, jump-puzzles with various difficulties, and a great storyline. A Masterpeice! If you like a challanging platformer/combat-sidescroller; this is it for you.

Originally got this game through a HumbleBundle and wasen't expecting much from it. Boy was I in for a surprise!

Pros and Cons:++ Pros:
+ Local coop
+ Responsive controls
+ Full controller support
+ Combat with a lot of variations
+ Customizations
+ Fun and fine story
+ Side-material (and loads of it)
+ Immersive world
+ Artstyle

- - Cons:
- Fairly short actual story
- Coop restricted to local

Details:The games features a coop mode, but this is however only on a local pc. The coop mode is essentialy adding another character to the game with next to none extra interactions. This is however a neat feature for the game, and is very fun. doubles the people, double the fun, right!? right indeed.

The combat and movement system is extremely good, you control every action, and your charactor is a super responsive slave to your controller of choice. It features full controller support, which I personally find great for this kind of game. Great use of combo variation and at some points it is even a necesity to win a duel or complete a challange.

Wether you jump your way thorugh spikes, traps and platforms, or (Guaca)melee your way through hazzards of enemies, It's allways a very good mixtures of the two main gameplay mechanics. The game has a lot of mechnics, which are all very well explained, and it forces you to utilizes almost everyone of them. You can't just stomp thorugh the game using one move, or one combat technique. Variation is key to defeat certain enemies.

One word *Sidematerial*!!! Side-quests (so to speak), challange modes, collectiables, unlockables. Guacamelee has pretty much all of it. It also featues a some custimization to suit your playstyle as well. Some of the challanges may be difficult and frustratin! I must admit I at one point spent 1½ hours completing a single jump-puzzle... I suck... damn my stubborness. And yet other parts may be a peice of cake.

The overall game is an eye-pleaser. The artline is amazing, especially considering it being a just" a 2D sidescroller. You can really feel the mood of the game
date: being pumped up with references to other games
recommended: memes and various sidestories. It's all in the detail of the tiny thing. And there is a lot of tiny things in this game. Makes for an overall better experience. It is very rewarding to go around exploring the world of guacamelee
hoursPlayed: trust me on this one!\n\nThe story is pretty straight-forward
voteText: humorous
helpfulPercent: filled with some unique characters. This is however not the bearing factor
votesHelpful: as it falls a bit short compared to the standard of the other parts of the game. Only problem is that you can rush through the main storyline in a matter of a few hours
votesTotal:
which leaves you storywise a bit dissatisfied. The loads of extra content largely outweights this problem though.

Final verdict:One of the best sidescrolles i've ever played. Rewarding to play.
"Me Gusta". I rate this game 9/10."

reviewText: A really cool platform adventure game. It is quite similar to the free game N in its gameplay and can be very addictive and really quite tough in places just like N. Has some similarity to the likes of Prince of Persia (1989) and Deadlight but has a much more advanced combat system and much more intricate puzzles making it really superior to those two. There's loads of side quests and ways to upgrade and change your character's abilities. Has a great story all the way through and superb presentation. I really recommend Guacamelee! highly.

reviewText:
STORY

So you play as your typical Joe (or should I say Juan?) who lives in his house on the desert near a Pueblucho, so forth you get called for help on the church and stay for a fiesta, but everything goes wrong and an evil dead lord called Carlos Calaca comes from the underworld to take the princ... governor´s daughter as a sacrifice. You get to know a lot of quirky characters along the way and transform into a LUCHADOR gaining abilities throughout the game and unlocking new costumes.

PRESENTATION

The game haves a very stylised look, very sharp and cartoony, which goes great with the Mexican theming, also is simplistic and runs at a great 60fps at all times with no delays or slowdown even if the screen is filled with enemies and enemy bits, also the game haves a great amount of references to other games ranging from indie titles to well known titles such as Zelda and Metroid.

GAMEPLAY

The game haves a really tight combat system wich lets you do huge combos, with few enemies but they get different mechanics and presented so differently throughout the game so the game feels always fresh unless you have to backtrack, also there are miniquests and hidden items for you to discover making the replay value go even higher.

CONCLUSION

Probably one of the best games out there, quiet a great experience and saticfying, leaving you wanting for more at the end.

Cons
-Cheap Last Boss Battle
-6 hours long to beat the main game

Pros
+Tight game
+Intuitive design
+Overall great game

8/10 GO BUY IT NOW

reviewText:
Guacamelee is another one of those action platformers set in quirky colorful world with an over the top story and a silly sense of humor. If you are like me and you are sick and tired of this genre I sincerely recommend you to try out Guacamelee.

At the first glance Guacamelee really seams just like any other game from this genre. What saves it from the awful fate of mediocrity is it's gameplay. While most games concentrate on one or two unique mechanics, in Guacamelee you have a wide variety of special moves that are use both for combat and traversing the environment, and sometimes for both tings at once. Which is cool, but isn't the thing that made me love this game. The awesome bit is that while the platforming is simple at first and requires you to use only one or two special abilities at once, later on you'll need to be able to preform very complex  combinations of you abilities. The satisfaction of pulling off some of the more challenging platforming segments is wonderful. And the same goes for combat. The only thing I didn't like about it is the pace at which you acquire new abilities. It's slow. I didn't notice the first time I played trough the game, but on my second run on hard mode in the beginning of the game I felt handicapped. Another thing I noticed only ind hard mode is that the boss hit boxes aren't all that grate. Every now and again fighting a boss I got hit by it's attack when the animation of that attack had already played out. If the game had been more combat oriented this had really been a big problem for me, but since I only noticed it a couple times on hard mode it's only a minor annoyance.

And wile the games artstyle doesn't  set it apart from all the other indie games, you can't deny that it looks quite nice. Simplified blocky shapes and the bold color pallet works well together. Wen it comes to the visual part of the game I only have tow criticisms. First - I have no idea why would anyone think that it's necessary to have a thick black line always present on the top of the screen. There definitely  has to be an more ascetically pleasing way to make the health and stamina meter always visible. Also there is no reason to have pause button prompt always be displayed at the top of the screen. Second - every now and again there ware situations when the color of a particular enemy matched the backgrounds color which made identifying their attacks difficult at times. And wile for the most of the game it's a non issue since health enemies aren't that strong and give a lot of health orbs once killed, if you are fighting a boss on hard mode where it can kill you in 5 or 6 hits it's a bit annoying not to be able to see it.

When it comes to the games story I really can't tell you anything. I read just the first four or five dialogs, realized that I absolutely didn't care and stopped reading. I really hope that there will come a day when indie devs will realize that many people don't care about the story in a game like this and will start to put in options that allow to skip story at faster pace. Because in Guacamelee you have to press a button for every line a characters says. It takes ages to click trough some of the more lengthier dialogs. And it absolutely enrages me when there is a conversation before a boss fight that is repeated every time that you try to defeat the boss. STOP THAT! No one wants to click trough that ♥♥♥♥ again and again. Good thing this game only has four instances of this.

All in all it's a surprisingly competent action platformer. It may lack the design elegance of games like Super Meat Boy, but it's grate no the less.

What can i say about this came other than, Amazing.
The experience i had with the game was perfect in almost everyway.

9.5/10 Would buy at full price

reviewText: Guacamelee is a 2D high-flying combo action and platforming game. The overall theme, music, and graphics are all blended together to make this game a very memorable and fun experience. Some levels or areas can be a bit frustrating as you will need to have precision control and some puzzles can be very tricky, just check out a walk-through or a video to get you passed these areas. There's a ton of content with unique achievements, challenges, hidden goodies, collectibles and costumes to unlock. The game also has a two-player option for local co-op bashing!
